Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Offer help or support when asked
Situation2: The acquaintance's car has broken down on a quiet road, and they are calling for assistance.
Story: It was a quiet Saturday afternoon when my phone buzzed with a message from my mom: “Hope you’re having a good weekend. Miss you!” I knew she expected me to check in, maybe call and chat for a while. I hadn’t spoken to my parents all week, and guilt pricked at me. I started typing a reply, promising myself I’d call after dinner. Just then, another call came in—this time from Mark, an acquaintance from work. His voice was tense, almost desperate. “Hey, sorry to bother you, but my car broke down on Maple Road. I don’t know who else to call. Can you help?” I glanced at the clock, feeling the weight of both expectations. My parents wanted to hear from me, to know I was okay and cared. Mark needed someone right now, stranded and anxious. My mind raced, torn between being the reliable son my parents hoped for and the helpful acquaintance Mark needed. I stared at my phone, heart pounding, caught between two worlds and unsure which to choose.
